content.h1: How to write your own Target
content.h5: Why would I want to write a Target?
content.p: If you want to write your trace messages to some non-standard output (for example to some management tool or over the network or using the PPPoP (PPP-over-pigeon protocol) you need to write a custom Target.

It's really easy. Create a class that inherits from NLog.Target and override the Write() method. In the body of the method use CompiledLayout.GetFormattedMessage() to get the message text, then send the text to the destination media.

content.h5: How to pass configuration options to the target?
content.p: Consider the above example. There's a property called "Host" that does just that. Having a public property that sets the required configuration parameters is enough for NLog to use it. Each attribute that you put in the definition gets passed to the appropriate public property. NLog takes care of the appropriate conversions necessary so that you can use integer, string, datetime, boolean parameters.
content.h5: Do I really need to create a separate DLL?
content.p: Not really. You can use TargetFactory.AddTarget() to register your target programmatically. Just be sure to to it at the very beginning of your program before any log messages are written. It should be possible to reference your EXE using the clause.
